documents.title: [Active] 2025 Consumer Core Operating Model Refinement & High-Level Objectives
documents.content:
ÔªøConsumer Core ‚Äì 2025 Domains‚Äô Objectives

                                                                                                                                              

________________





Doc metadata

Author

	Adam Ghanem

	Contributors

	Abdelrahman Hussein

	Last updated on

	Sep 4, 2024

	Document breakdown & status

	1. HOW: Background & Operating Model Evolution Revising

2. WHAT: Focus for 2025 & beyond Active

3. ORG: Target tribe structures for 2025, 2026 & beyond Parked

	What needs to be reviewed?

	What do we need feedback on?

* Open questions for later

* ‚Ä¶ 

	Background & Operating Model Evolution

and how we plan to use that to set our strategic objectives for YP2025 & beyond‚Ä¶

Purpose of document

In this document we at tempt to provide a high-level overview of the current tribe, its domains, operating model and challenges. We use those inputs along with the help of a bit of refinement of our operating model and introducing a bit of terminology to help us steer our focus for key investments for 2025. This doesn‚Äôt serve as a replacement for the YP2025 but rather as a strategic starting point to help us align within our tribe & externally with our stakeholders on (a) our ambition, priority and appetite across our owned domains, as well as (b) use this is as a chance to refine our mission, vision and operating model for the tribe as we head in 2025 & beyond. 

Current Structure & Domains (Platforms) Owned

üî¨Vision ‚áí "Core actions" can be completed at all times, quickly and with minimal frustration, even as HelloFresh's business grows.

Core actions: log in, register account, save address, activate/reactivate/cancel plan, calculate price, place order, manage delivery plan, manage/schedule delivery

üéØMission ‚áí Build a reliable, high-performing and scalable backend to power HelloFresh‚Äôs core actions.

Domains we own ‚áí customer authentication, customer account management, customer address, subscription, order, deliveries, delivery plan and price calculation; we also maintain Intfood (‚ÄúBob‚Äù) and API-v2

  



Operating Model

Is there any additional context I need to be aware of to help me better understand the operating model?

Consumer Core, operating as a backend-only tribe, is responsible for the invisible yet critical processes and systems powering HelloFresh's customer experience. Our current architecture, mostly based on legacy monoliths (Bob, API-v2, Intfood) and databases, while functional, limits our ability to rapidly innovate and scale. The complexity of the existing codebase and the shared database structure pose significant challenges to both development agility (27% lower LTTC than other services when working on the monoliths), system performance (TTR for monoliths is at 138 min vs. 97 min for other services) and minimizing our security risks (TK CVEs that can‚Äôt be addressed due to X)[a] [source].





As we modernize, we must support both legacy and new systems simultaneously. This dual support significantly increases our KTLO (Keep The Lights On) workload beyond allocated resources (30~50% sprint over sprint average goal miss-rate), frequent timeline shifts and increased legacy system incidents & issues. These factors often slow our modernization efforts, as we sometimes need to prioritize short-term gains (e.g. Project Bolt, Next Day Delivery Activations UK Launch, Free Breakfast for Life) over long-term improvements. Balancing immediate business needs with strategic modernization remains a key challenge, underscoring the urgency of our initiatives to streamline and update our systems.





 add strategies in incremental ‚Äì that says like some fraud prevention enhancements with problems to be solved

[bd]Added this for discussion





How are we making sure we have clients aligned to start consuming newer APIs like Plans API instead of subscription API from legacy systems.

[be]@adam.ghanem@hellofresh.com to update after:

1. Scorecards of status quo established

2. Gap analysis

3. Target maturity for 2025 established based on YP exercise

_Assigned to adam.ghanem@hellofresh.com_

[bf]this already exist

[bg]Can you expand on what you mean here by this?





In my mind here, I am referring to the ability for a customer to be able to:

1. Schedule an ad-hoc order delivery

2. Select meals for that delivery





This will allow customers to either:

1. Place one time orders whenever they'd like

2. Place and schedule one time orders throughout the week as well

[bh]@ahus@hellofresh.com while we wait for your answer, I assume that what is currently supported is to  create an order without a subscription, and what Adam is referring to would add a new delivery to an existing subscription. 

Is that the case?

[bi]@adam.ghanem@hellofresh.com what is the difference between placing an order whenever they'd like and throughout the week? (1 and 2?)

[bj]I just mentioned it here for now based on little input I got from Augusto so that we just don‚Äôt forget about it. 





I believe the mapping exercise you have scheduled for tomorrow would clarify _some_ of the ambiguity here of the necessary capabilities :) so would hold off any technical analysis needed at this point & see after tomorrow‚Äôs workshop how best for articulate this

[bk]For context, the original idea that Augusto mentioned is being able to have multiple deliveries scheduled automatically in a week

[bl]Shouldn't this be a pricing strategy that has a dependency on the subscription/plans domain?

[bm]Pricing the subscription is ‚Äì the ability to build a subscription using building blocks is a "subscriptions" domain concern ‚Äì this is still open for discussion though and still early here

[bn]@ahus@hellofresh.com the starting point or need is pricing monetization driven -- we can discuss which team is more suited to build this.

[bo]who are consumers of this?

[bp]I am just putting it as a placeholder here ‚Äì I am not sure if this is something that was ever done before but not sure who should do it

### EMAIL: Notes: ‚ÄúIan:Nikita 1:1 (2w)‚Äù Dec 5, 2025
ID: 19aef619891691a0
From: Gemini <gemini-notes@google.com>
----------------------------------------

Notes from ‚ÄúIan:Nikita 1:1 (2w)‚Äù



These notes have been sent to invited guests in your organization.



Open meeting notes



The content was auto-generated on December 5, 2025, 5:37 PM CET and may  

contain errors.





Summary



Ian Brooks and Nikita Gorshkov discussed the challenges of poor  

personalization, including menu repeats, resulting from the current  

recommendation engine, which Ian Brooks suggested requires a UX overhaul  

using a more food-based, "restaurant"-style approach for "total choice for  

chef's plate" implementation. Nikita Gorshkov confirmed the leadership for  

the creator platform/marketplace will be Lineia Serisma for product  

strategy, Cole Banning for growth, and Melanie Schmidt for project  

management, with an MVP focused on simple, occasion-based boxes for one-off  

purchases via social media. They also addressed the organization of Market  

Innovation, with Nikita Gorshkov proposing a new prioritization structure,  

and Ian Brooks agreeing to serve as the delegate for international markets  

while emphasizing the need for guardrails to mitigate US market dominance  

in resource allocation.





Suggested next steps





Ian Brooks will send the three videos about the menu personalization issues  

to Nikita Gorshkov.



Nikita Gorshkov will circle back to Lineia Serisma and Cole Banning to  

discuss the sales and outreach program for the creator platform.



Nikita Gorshkov will consolidate a proposal on how the input of new items  

will work for the market innovation and optimization squad.

### EMAIL: Notes: ‚ÄúSameer:Nikita 1:1‚Äù Dec 5, 2025
ID: 19aef106eee63b22
From: Gemini <gemini-notes@google.com>
----------------------------------------

Notes from ‚ÄúSameer:Nikita 1:1‚Äù



These notes have been sent to invited guests in your organization.



Open meeting notes



The content was auto-generated on December 5, 2025, 4:08 PM CET and may  

contain errors.





Summary



Sameer Doda confirmed that the overall work volume is manageable, with  

Allison assisting on the platform and Good Chop Shopify projects, though  

Sameer Doda and Nikita Gorshkov noted that program revivals are unlikely  

due to a lack of resources, a point Sameer Doda, David, and Nikita Gorshkov  

discussed with Marina regarding unfunded work. Sameer Doda detailed their  

involvement in the complex Good Chop Shopify project, the DACH Juices  

support project for Nordic markets that requires a technical solution, and  

the Influencer Marketplace, which needs an MVP path forward due to varied  

stakeholder views and already has design progress with Shay; Sameer Doda  

and Nikita Gorshkov agreed on a simple one-time purchase customer journey  

for the MVP, but Sameer Doda raised concerns about limitations with  

applying vouchers and selling add-ons, which Nikita Gorshkov suggested  

discussing with Jama, and both acknowledged a need for more frontend  

development resources. Sameer Doda needs to coordinate with Jama for the  

roadmap review meeting and discussed the "Seamless Pricing Upgrade"  

initiative, which Nikita Gorshkov suggested de-prioritizing, while they  

also agreed to maintain two different views of the roadmap and im



ace.



Sameer Doda will go through the answers received from Viola regarding the  

duck juices support and create a requirements document, including an  

estimate for when the work will be picked up in Q1.



Sameer Doda will set up a session next week with Nikita Gorshkov and Shay  

to (1) review the basic customer journey for the onetime purchase flow and  

the low fidelity designs for the influencer marketplace, and (2) work with  

Shay to iron out changes needed on the low fidelity designs so Shay can  

continue working on the high fidelity designs.



Sameer Doda and Nikita Gorshkov will connect with Jamba on Monday to  

discuss the roadmap review meeting with stakeholders and determine the  

invitees.

### EMAIL: Notes: ‚ÄúNikita / Prateek (Deep Dive)‚Äù Dec 5, 2025
ID: 19aee849b6c7c509
From: Gemini <gemini-notes@google.com>
----------------------------------------

Notes from ‚ÄúNikita / Prateek (Deep Dive)‚Äù



These notes have been sent to invited guests in your organization.



Open meeting notes



The content was auto-generated on December 5, 2025, 1:36 PM CET and may  

contain errors.





Summary



Nikita Gorshkov and Prateek Jajoo discussed content strategy and app  

development, acknowledging a weak history in content but recognizing the  

potential of an app to measure and communicate pet health improvements to  

users, with the goal of improving social proof and retention. They agreed  

on the need to define the smallest possible product and to test ideas by  

understanding pet owners' top worries through a survey, which Nikita  

Gorshkov confirmed the commercial team can easily incorporate into existing  

surveys. Prateek Jajoo inquired about the power user demographics, whom  

Nikita Gorshkov identified as "dinks" in metro areas, with high annual  

spending on their pets.





Suggested next steps





Prateek Jajoo will start work on the login page and write a one-pager to  

review and make stage one and stage two plans for a quick win within one  

sprint.



Nikita Gorshkov will help Prateek Jajoo navigate where to find the survey  

and related information by sending the contact for Lindsay and adding  

Prateek Jajoo to the TPT team for visibility on the surveys.



Prateek Jajoo will work with the designer Katrina to ensure the right  

questions are being asked in the survey to get the right information.



Nikita Gorshkov will ensure that Katrina has the bandwidth for the design  

work.

Summary



The session, attended by Travis Provick, Nikita Gorshkov, Sergei Kuzmenko,  

Leo Lee, Evan, Hoga, Talis, Adam, Mark, Tommaso, Fiona, and Tessa, focused  

on a bottom-up planning exercise for the tribe to prioritize initiatives,

color-coded sheet to assess priority and confidence levels for Q1  

deliverables. Key discussions involved the shift to React Native, Appio  

deprecation, the high priority of multi-region readiness for Project 500,  

and the need to prioritize Snowplow implementation for personalization  

signals, which currently lacks ownership despite being a blocker for meta  

backlog items. Critical items requiring further scoping and dependency  

management include the scalable food profile architecture and a long-term  

solution for the seamless downgrade issue, which is the highest priority  

for the merchandising team.
